hints.content:
The polar form of the complex number $A$ is 

$\qquad\begin{align}8\left(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{6}+i\sin\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)&=8\left(\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}+i\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\\\\&=4\sqrt3+4i.\end{align}$

This is the rectangular form of $A$.  The real coordinate is $\green{4\sqrt3}$ and the imaginary coordinate is $\blue4$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/96059ecf3dd6c5378b11bcccaa95d292fdce886a.png) 

What is the rectangular form of $B$?

Since $B$ is the reflection of $A$ across the real axis, the rectangular form of $B$ is 

$\qquad4\sqrt3-4i=6.9+(-4)i$,

rounded to the nearest tenth.
The rectangular form of $B\,$ is $\,6.9+(-4)i$.

question.content:
The point $A$ in the complex plane below represents a complex number whose polar form is

$\qquad 8\left(\cos\dfrac{\pi}{6}+i\,\sin\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)\,.$

**What is the rectangular form of the complex number represented by the point $B?$**

The rectangular form of $B$  is [[☃ input-number 1]]$\,+\,\,$[[☃ input-number 2]]$\,\,i$.

Express your answers in decimal form, rounded to the nearest tenth.


![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3986721adf2c589a3bbf009fb2bdcc89d325dc63.png)

hints.content:
The polar form of the complex number $A$ is 

$\qquad\begin{align}6\left(\cos \dfrac{2\pi}{3}+i\sin\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\right)&=6\left(-\dfrac{1}{2}+i\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}\right)\\\\&=-3+3\sqrt3i.\end{align}$

This is the rectangular form of $A$.  The real coordinate is $\green{-3}$ and the imaginary coordinate is $\blue{3\sqrt3}$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/87ab1c2bb29b9164426859079a026c9a486d6b43.png) 

What is the rectangular form of $B$?

Since $B$ is the reflection of $A$ across the  imaginary  axis, the rectangular form of $B$ is 

$\qquad-3-3\sqrt3i=-3-5.2i$.
The rectangular form of $B\,$ is $-3+(-5.2)i$.

This is the rectangular form of $A$.  The real coordinate is $\green{\dfrac52}$ and the imaginary coordinate is $\blue{\dfrac{5\sqrt3}{2}}$.

$\qquad\begin{align}7\left(\cos \dfrac{7\pi}{6}+i\sin\dfrac{7\pi}{6}\right)&=7\left(-\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}-\dfrac{1}{2}i\right)\\\\&=-\dfrac{7\sqrt3}{2}-\dfrac72i.\end{align}$

This is the rectangular form of $A$.  The real coordinate is $\green{-\dfrac{7\sqrt3}{2}}$ and the imaginary coordinate is $\blue{-\dfrac72}$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/81dfbd7d76bd11fa0b274899d41f185bbbe118e8.png) 

What is the rectangular form of $B$?

$\qquad \dfrac{7\sqrt3}{2}+\dfrac72i=6.1+3.5i$,

rounded to the nearest tenth.
The rectangular form of $B\,$ is $\,6.1+3.5i$.

hints.content:
The polar form of the complex number $A$ is 

$\qquad\begin{align}8\left(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{6}+i\sin\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right)&=8\left(\dfrac{\sqrt3}{2}+i\dfrac{1}{2}\right)\\\\&=4\sqrt3+4i.\end{align}$

This is the rectangular form of $A$.  The real coordinate is $\green{4\sqrt3}$ and the imaginary coordinate is $\blue 4$. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ec93ad587fd8991c06e61e29453769921811f504.png) 

What is the rectangular form of $B$?

Since $B$ makes the same angle as  $A$ with the positive real axis, and its distance from the origin is $4$, the polar form of $B$ is 

$\qquad 4\left(\cos\dfrac{\pi}{6}+i\,\sin\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right).$

The two triangles shown above are similar, so the rectangular coordinates of $B$ are one-half those of $A$:

$\qquad\,2\sqrt3+2i=3.5+2i$,

rounded to the nearest tenth.
The rectangular form of $B\,$ is $\,3.5+2i$.

This is the rectangular form of $A$.  The real coordinate is $\green{\dfrac{5.5\sqrt2}{2}}$ and the imaginary coordinate is $\blue{-\dfrac{5.5\sqrt2}{2}}$.

hints.content: From the polar form of $A$, we see that the absolute value of $A$, or its distance from the origin, is $4$.  We see from the graph that the absolute value of $B$ is also $4$, so $A$ and $B$ have the same absolute value.

The angle $A$ makes with the positive real axis  $\dfrac{13\pi}{2}$ .  If we plot this point, we see that the points make different angles with the positive real axis. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/005e0b603f74c345b94c11ff4f4cde85d7f1a9c1.png)

Therefore $A$ and $B$ are not equal.  They have the same absolute value,  but make different angles with the positive real axis.

The only correct choice is:

* $A$ and $B$ have the same absolute value, but they make  different angles with the positive real axis.

and $B$ is a point in the complex plane below.

$A$ and $B$  make the same angle with the positive real axis, but they do not have the same absolute value.
$A$ and $B$ have the same absolute value, but they make  different angles with the positive real axis.

hints.content:
The polar form of the complex number $A$ is 

$\qquad r(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)\,$,

where $r$ is the distance of $A$ from the origin, and $\theta$ is the angle $A$ makes with the positive real axis.  The polar form is not unique, since we can add any multiple of $2\pi$ to $\theta$ and get the same complex number.

The angle $B$ makes with the positive real axis is the same as that for $A$, so the angle is $\theta$.  We see that the distance from the origin is one-half the distance of $A$ from the origin, so the distance is $\dfrac{r}{2}$ .


Therefore the polar form of $B$ is 

$\qquad \dfrac{r}{2}(\cos(\theta)+i\sin(\theta)).$

Since $\cos(2\pi+\theta)=\cos\theta$ and $\sin(2\pi+\theta)=\sin\theta$,  another correct answer is 

$\qquad \dfrac{r}{2}(\cos(2\pi+\theta)+i\sin(2\pi+\theta)).$

Polar forms of $B$ are:

* $ \dfrac{r}{2}(\cos(2\pi+\theta)+i\sin(2\pi+\theta))$

* $ \dfrac{r}{2}(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta).$

question.content:
The point $A$ represents the complex number $a+b \,i$ in the complex plane below. Point $B$ is the midpoint of the segment connecting point $A$ and the origin.

**Which of the following are correct polar forms of the complex number represented by the point $B?$**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4ab658bd14948ffb62a613f82c8c952b6c3ce78e.png)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
The polar form of the complex number $A$ is 

$\qquad r(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)\,$,

where $r$ is the distance of $A$ from the origin, and $\theta$ is the angle $A$ makes with the positive real axis.  The polar form is not unique, since we can add any multiple of $2\pi$ to $\theta$ and get the same complex number.

We see that $B$ is half the distance from the origin as $A$, so the distance is $\,\dfrac{r}{2}$ . We see also that the angle $B$ makes with the positive real axis is $\pi+\theta$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e72176fdd6a7ccf7565df1d5372e1e48d0a583ac.png)

Therefore the polar form of $B$ is 

$\qquad \dfrac{r}{2}(\cos(\pi+\theta)+i\sin(\pi+\theta)).$

Since $\cos(\pi+\theta)=-\cos\theta$ and $\sin(\pi+\theta)=-\sin\theta$,  another correct answer is 

$\qquad \dfrac{r}{2}(-\cos\theta-i\sin\theta).$

Polar forms of $B$ are:

* $ \dfrac{r}{2}(\cos(\pi+\theta)+i\sin(\pi+\theta))$

* $ \dfrac{r}{2}(-\cos\theta-i\sin\theta).$

question.content:
The point $A$ represents the complex number $a+b \,i$ in the complex plane below. 

**Which of the following are correct polar forms of the complex number represented by the point $B$ for any angle $\theta~$?**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/794309438e25e432f6306d8f40281b4e98fce220.png)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
The polar form of the complex number $A$ is 

$\qquad r(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)\,$,

where $r$ is the distance of $A$ from the origin, and $\theta$ is the angle $A$ makes with the positive real axis.  The polar form is not unique, since we can add any multiple of $2\pi$ to $\theta$ and get the same complex number.

Since $A$ and $B$ are the same distance from the origin,  $r$ is the same for both numbers. We see also that the angle $B$ makes with the positive real axis is $\pi-\theta$.  

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7cbfbc96138fc7e816993fb020f32313a7ce2a3e.png)

Therefore the polar form of $B$ is 

$\qquad r(\cos(\pi-\theta)+i\sin(\pi-\theta)).$

Since $\cos(\pi-\theta)=-\cos\theta$ and $\sin(\pi-\theta)=\sin\theta$,  another correct answer is 

$\qquad r(-\cos\theta+i\sin\theta).$

In addition, $\cos(\theta-\pi)=-\cos(\theta)$ and $\sin(\theta-\pi)=-\sin\theta$, so 

$\qquad r(\cos(\theta-\pi)-i\sin(\theta-\pi))$

is also a correct answer.

Polar forms of $B$ are:

* $ r(\cos(\pi-\theta)+i\sin(\pi-\theta))$

* $ r(-\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)$

* $r(\cos(\theta-\pi)-i\sin(\theta-\pi))$.

question.content:
The point $A$ represents the complex number $a+b \,i$ in the complex plane below. 

**Which of the following are correct polar forms of the complex number represented by the point $B?$**

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f9ec40a12af3b34728673b5183dbae5756be90ae.png)

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
The polar form of a complex number is 

$\qquad r(\cos\theta+i\sin\theta)$,

where $r$ is the distance from $A$ to the origin, and $\theta$ is the angle the line $OA$ makes with the positive real axis.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/45f0e6a264ad7b93174e63f0923914172d8378cc.png)

By the Pythagorean Theorem, we have

$\qquad r=\sqrt{(\green{-5})^2+\blue2^2}=\sqrt{29}\approx5.4.$

To find $\theta$, we observe that 

$\qquad \tan\theta=-\dfrac25=-0.4$.

We get

$\qquad\begin{align}\theta&=\tan^{-1}\left(-0.4\right)\\&\approx -0.38\,\text{radians},\end{align}$ 

since the inverse tangent is an angle between $-\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ and $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$.

We see from the graph that  $\theta$ in this case is between $\dfrac{\pi}{2}$ and $\pi$, so we have

$\qquad\begin{align}\theta&=\pi-0.38\\&\approx 3.14-0.38\\&\approx2.8\,\text{radians},\end{align}$ 

 rounded to the nearest tenth.

Here is the point plotted in polar coordinates:

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/acf99aece1dd4d17f815ed8147db39299a0d2fa2.png)
The polar form of $A\,$ is $\,5.4(\cos(2.8)+i\sin(2.8))$.

hints.content:
The most important property of the imaginary unit $i$ is:
 
 $\qquad \blue{i ^ 2} = \pink{-1}$

Therefore:
 
$\qquad \begin{align}  i ^ 4 &=\left (\blue{i ^ 2}\right) ^ 2 \\
&= (\pink{-1}) ^ 2 \\
&= 1 \end{align}$

So, we can simplify the expression by rewriting it in terms of $i^4$.

Because $9 \div \blue{4} = \green{2}$ with remainder $ \red{1}$: 

 $ \qquad \begin{eqnarray} i ^ {9} &=& \left(i^\blue{4}\right)^\green{2} \cdot i^\red{1} \\ &=& (1)^\green{2} \cdot i^\red{1} \\ &=& i^\red{1} \\ &=&i\end{eqnarray} $

Let's use the fact that $i^2=-1$ to convert  the given complex number to the form $a+bi$.  

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{20}&=(i^2)^{10}\\&=(-1)^{10}\\&=1.\end{align}$

For $i^{30}$, we have

So

question.content:
**Write the complex number** 

$\qquad  i^{20} + i^{30}$ 

**in the form $a+bi,$ where $i=\sqrt{-1}$ and $a$ and $b$ are real numbers.**

[[☃ expression 1]]

hints.content: A complex number has the form $a+bi$, where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers and $i^2=-1$.  If $b=0$, then the complex number is real.  Let's look at the various answer choices.

The numbers all require some simplification.  First, we have

$\qquad\begin{align}i^3&=i^2\cdot i\\&=(-1)\cdot i\\
&=-i,\end{align}$

and

$\qquad\begin{align}i^7&=i^6\cdot i\\&=(i^2)^3 \cdot  i\\&=(-1)^3\cdot i\\&=-i,\end{align}$

so 

$\qquad \begin{align}i^8&=-i \cdot i\\&=-i^2\\&=-(-1)=1.\end{align}$

In addition, 

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{22}&=(i^2)^{11}\\&=(-1)^{11} \\&=-1,\end{align}$

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{32}&=(i^2)^{16}\\&=(-1)^{16} \\&=1,\end{align}$

and

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{101}&=(i^2)^{50}\cdot i\\&=(-1)^{50}\cdot i \\&=i.\end{align}$

Therefore 


$\qquad\begin{align}0.45i-6i^3&=0.45i-6(-i)\\&=0.45i+6i\\&=6.45i,\end{align}$

so this number is complex, and 

$\qquad\begin{align}4i^7+i^8&=-4i+1,\end{align}$

so this number is also complex.

In addition, 


$\qquad\begin{align}-4i+4i^{101}&=-4i+4i\\&=0,\end{align}$

$\qquad\begin{align}1-2i^{32}&=1-2(1)\\&=-1,\end{align}$

and

$\qquad\begin{align}5i^{22}+2&=5(-1)+2\\&=-3,\end{align}$

so these numbers are all real.

 and 

$\qquad \begin{align}0.6i^2+1&=0.6(-1)+1\\&=0.4,\end{align}$ 

so these numbers are real.  

Also, 

$\qquad2i-3i=-i$,

so this number is complex.

For the other numbers, we see first that

&=-i,\end{align}$

and

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{10}&=(i^2)^5\\&=(-1)^5\\&=-1.\end{align}$

Then


$\qquad\begin{align}i^3-6i&=-i-6i\\&=-7i,\end{align}$

so this number is complex, and

$\qquad\begin{align}3-4i^{10}&=3-4(-1)\\&=7.\end{align}$

This number is real.

hints.content: A complex number has the form $a+bi$, where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers and $i^2=-1$.  If $b=0$, then the complex number is real.  Let's look at the various answer choices.

First, we see that 

$\qquad \begin{align}1+i+i^2&=1+i-1\\&=i.\end{align}$

For the other numbers, let's simplify the first power of $i$ that occurs in each answer.

We have

$\qquad\begin{align}i^4&=(i^2)^2\\&=(-1)^2\\&=1,\end{align}$

so 

$\qquad\begin{align}i^8&=(i^4)^2\\&=1.\end{align}$

Also, 

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{11}&=(i^2)^5\cdot i\\&=(-1)^5\cdot i\\&=-i\end{align}$

and 

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{100}&=(i^2)^{50}\\&=(-1)^{50}\\&=1.\end{align}$

Then, 

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{4}+i^5+i^6&=1+i^4\cdot i+i^4\cdot i^2\\&=1+i-1\\&=i,\end{align}$

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{8}+i^9+i^{10}&=1+i^8\cdot i+i^8\cdot i^2\\&=1+i-1\\&=i,\end{align}$

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{100}+i^{101}+i^{102}&=1+i^{100}\cdot i+i^{100}\cdot i^2\\&=1+i-1\\&=i,\end{align}$

so these are all complex.

$\qquad\begin{align}i^{11}+i^{12}+i^{13}&=-i+i^{11}\cdot i+i^{11}\cdot i^2\\&=-i-i\cdot i-i(-1)\\&=-i+1+i\\&=1,
\end{align}$


so this number is real.

hints.content: A complex number has the form $a+bi$, where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers and $i^2=-1$.  If $b=0$, then the complex number is real.  Let's simplify the powers of $i$ in each of the answer choices.

First, we see that

$\qquad \begin{align} i^4&=(i^2)^2\\&=(-1)^2\\&=1.\end{align}$

This tells us that 

$\qquad \begin{align}i^5&=i^4\cdot i\\&=i,\end{align}$

$\qquad \begin{align}i^6&=i^4 \cdot i^2\\&=i^2, \end{align}$

and in general,

$\qquad \begin{align}i^n&=i^4\cdot i^{n-4}\\&=i^{n-4}, \end{align}$


for integers $n\geq 4$.  

What does this tell us about *all* of the answer choices?

All of the answer choices are equal to $0$, because

$\qquad \begin{align}i-i^5&=i-i\\&=0,\end{align}$

and


$\qquad \begin{align}i^2-i^6&=i^2-i^2\\&=0,\end{align}$


and so on.  In every example, the second term is $i^4=1$ times the first term.  All of the numbers are equal to zero, and so they are all  real.

Real numbers:

* $i-i^5$
*  $i^2-i^6$ 
* $i^3-i^7$
* $i^4-i^8$
* $i^5-i^9$

There are no complex numbers that are not real.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/049d56458812b89a6596fbeef59ff482116dc090.png)

 By the Pythagorean Theorem, we have:

$\qquad \begin{align}\text{distance between } z \text{ and } {w}&=(\green{8})^2+(\blue{3})^2\\&=\sqrt{73}\\&=8.5,\end{align}$

rounded to the nearest tenth.

$\qquad \begin{align}|z-w|&=|(-3-4i)-(5-7i)|\\&=|-8+3\,i\,|\\&=\sqrt{73}.\end{align}$

$\qquad \begin{align}\dfrac{z+w}{2}&=\dfrac{(-3-4i)+(5-7i)}{2}\\&=\dfrac{2-11i}{2}\\\\&=1-5.5i.\end{align}$
